close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (fields: options, tid, itc, data_already_pending, have_new, listen_fd, was_quiesced, listen_nonblk, connections_tail, urh_tail)
struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle (fields: in_buffer_size, out_buffer_size, in_buffer_used, out_buffer_used, connection, prev, clean_ready)
MHD_accept_connection (function) and whether it can fail/abort or be noreturn
call_handlers (function) and whether it can fail/abort or be noreturn
MHD_cleanup_connections (function) and whether it can fail/abort or be noreturn
explanation: To decide whether any branch or statement in internal_run_from_select is statically unreachable you must know: (1) the daemon data layout/fields (options, flags, lists, fds) because many branches test those members; (2) the connection and upgrade-handle structures because loops and termination checks depend on their fields; (3) compile-time feature macros (HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE) which enable/disable whole blocks; (4) option/constant values (MHD_USE_SELECT_INTERNALLY, MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, FD_SETSIZE) that make conditions always true/false; (5) helper predicates/macros that affect branching (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_SCKT_FD_FITS_FDSET_SETSIZE_, FD_ISSET and the thread-ID checks) so you can determine whether the branches using them are reachable; (6) ITC accessor/clear functions (MHD_itc_r_fd_, MHD_itc_clear_) because they are used to decide early action; and (7) the callee functions (new_connections_list_process_, MHD_accept_connection, call_handlers, MHD_cleanup_connections, urh_from_fdset, process_urh, MHD_connection_finish_forward_, MHD_resume_connection) and whether any of them never return (noreturn/abort/longjmp) or always change daemon state in a way that makes subsequent code unreachable. Each listed symbol can change the truth value of conditions or the control flow (including non-returning callees), so they are required to conclude whether any code in internal_run_from_select is unreachable per the MISRA rule.
